questions.question: What is the standard formula for calculating the total cell potential ($E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}$)?
questions.explanation: To find the potential difference, you subtract the potential of the oxidation site (anode) from the potential of the reduction site (cathode).

questions.question: A cell has a cathode with $E^{\circ} = +0.80$ V and an anode with $E^{\circ} = -0.76$ V. What is the $E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}$?
If the calculated $E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}$ for a redox reaction is negative, the reaction is:
questions.explanation: A negative cell potential means the reaction requires an external energy source to proceed and will not happen naturally in that direction.

questions.question: When reversing a half-reaction to show it as an oxidation, what happens to the sign of its $E^{\circ}$ value if you are using the 'Addition Method' ($E^{\circ}_{\text{red}} + E^{\circ}_{\text{ox}}$)?
questions.explanation: While the standard subtraction formula handles the sign automatically, if you look at it as a sum of potentials, the oxidation potential is the negative of the reduction potential.

questions.question: In a spontaneous Galvanic cell, the species with the ________ reduction potential always acts as the cathode.
questions.explanation: The 'stronger' oxidizer (higher $E^{\circ}$) will successfully pull electrons and undergo reduction at the cathode.

questions.question: What is the $E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}$ for the reaction: $\text{Zn(s)} + \text{Cu}^{2+}\text{(aq)} \rightarrow \text{Zn}^{2+}\text{(aq)} + \text{Cu(s)}$? (Given $E^{\circ}_{\text{Cu}} = +0.34$ V, $E^{\circ}_{\text{Zn}} = -0.76$ V)
questions.explanation: Copper is the cathode, Zinc is the anode. $0.34 - (-0.76) = 1.10$ V.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT affect the standard cell potential ($E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}$)?
options: The surface area of the electrodes
The chemical identity of the substances
The concentration of the electrolytes (if not $1$ M)
questions.explanation: Voltage is an intensive property; adding more mass or surface area might increase the current (amps) or the life of the battery, but it doesn't change the potential (volts).

questions.question: If you calculate a cell potential to be $0.00$ V, the system is:
questions.explanation: When the potential difference between the two compartments is zero, there is no driving force for electrons to move.

questions.question: Calculate the potential of a cell using the $\text{Ag}^+/\text{Ag}$ ($+0.80$ V) and $\text{Al}^{3+}/\text{Al}$ ($-1.66$ V) half-cells.
What happens to the $E_{\text{cell}}$ (non-standard) as the reactants are consumed in a working battery?
options: It stays constant until it hits zero
It depends only on the volume of the salt bridge
questions.explanation: As the reaction proceeds, the concentrations move away from $1$ M toward equilibrium, causing the voltage to drop (described by the Nernst Equation).

scoreMessages.90: Perfect! You're ready to design your own batteries.
scoreMessages.70: Great job! You've mastered the potential difference calculations.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Watch those double negatives! Subtracting a negative is adding.
